column4: NVIDA is so dodgy on ubuntu. I think i have to go back to windows O_0
what's the trouble?

NVIDIA doesn't detect the full resolution of my monitor, so everything is stretched horizontally. I've tried to use xradr to create a new modeline/resolution but it fails. Although that's not the worst of it - whenever I boot into ubuntu, it's like my desktop has 'zoomed' in, and I have to move my mouse to the corners of the screen for it to pann to the menu. Then I end up having to chose the same resolution, which fixes the issue and rescales it back into
and you've tried changing the resolution using nvidia-settings?
you're talking about the NVIDIA X server settings in system/admin?
then yes.
NVIDIA seems to be the problem in this situation, not a saviour. I've tried writing the settings to the xorg.conf file.
have you tried backing up your old xorg.conf and writing a fresh one instead of merging?
How do I do that?
write a new one, that is.
okay, I just tried to create a new one with NVIDIA: "Unable to create new X config backup file '/etc/X11/xorg.conf.backup'"
you need to use sudo before it'll be able to write to /etc directly, or you can have it write to a file in your home directory and copy it across with sudo afterwards
I can't save it anywhere but in the location it specifies.
are you sure? are you looking at X server display configuration?
there's a save to X configuration file button at the bottom of that section, clicking that will give you the option to save to another location and merge with the existing xorg or not
No, that's just asking you to point it to the location of your xorg.conf file.. I tried to create a new empty file on the desktop named xorg.conf but it won't write to it.
ok, try the show preview button and just copy and paste the new xorg config
I've got 2 xorg.conf in my x11 directory. One named xorg.conf and the other xorg.conf.20090420200128
copy the current version to xorg.conf.bak and replace with the freshly generated output from nvidia-settings
you are capable of copying your xorg.conf.bak back in the event that x fails to start, right?
Okay i'm going to reboot and see if it helps. thanks mate.
